For two even factors, either the trapezoid has a multiple of four lines, in which case the total is an odd multiple of two (a contradiction), or it has an odd multiple of 2 lines, in which case the total is odd (a contradiction). This means that all potential trapezoidal decompositions of G must be based on factors one of which is odd, and the other of which is a multiple of the highest power 2 that is a factor of G.

G is not odd, but I add this third case just for completeness. For an odd number n, it can be factored into two factors greater than 1 and less than n, min and max (unless n is a square and min and max are both the square root of n). n can be expressed as the sum of min successive integers centered on max, or as the sum of max integers centered on min. The second case will dip into integers below 1, and not be truly trapezoidal (by my reading of it), if min < max / 2. So I get somewhere between the number of distinct pair factorizations and twice that number.

This is pretty much the approach I took when I came up with post #5.  The only difference being that I started by coming up with processes that gave me definite answers for lower numbers e.g. 36, then 10 and 14, and generalizing those results such that they should cover all numbers.

I wish I could sleep instead of thinking about this over and over again. Instead, I offer a possible solution to the googol question without using logs of large numbers.

First, say that an even number n is the product of two even factors. There is no trapezoidal decomposition based on this factorization (see below, this post is out of space).

So, in examining an even number for trapezoidal decompositions, we can only look at cases where n is an even number that is factored into one odd factor and one even, named ODD and EVEN. For each pair (ODD, EVEN), n can be represented as a) The sum of ODD successive integers around EVEN, and b) The sum of 2*EVEN successive integers around ODD/2.

But I want to discount cases using integers less than 1. For the first case to fit in positive integers, EVEN > ODD/2. For the second case to fit, ODD > 2*EVEN, or EVEN < ODD/2. Since ODD/2 cannot equal EVEN, then either the first inequality holds or the second, but not neither. So the number of trapezoidal representations of a number with both odd and even factors is the number of distinct odd factors, of which G has 100, and I get exactly Jim’s result in post 11. It just wasn't clear to me that 5^n was the number of lines in some cases and twice the center in others (where there were an even number of lines).

Regarding America's alleged military decline, it is worth noting that per SIPRI, the Cold War era defense spending peaked in 1985, when the US accounted for 30% of world defense spending. In 2011, SIPRI says that the US accounted for 41% of world defense spending.

Instead of starting a good conservative dialog on what the US is defending itself against with such massive expenditures (is there a threat that today that surpasses the Cold War ear Soviet Union?), and whether the US serves its own interests by being so entangled militarily with the world, Brooks seeks to scare us with the bogey of "military decline".

I also want to say to Brooks and the New York Times, with the democratization of information via the world wide web, a reader of the NYT, in less time than it takes to read a week's worth of newspaper, can gather and digest the basic facts around such things as Medicare and defense expenditures. You have to up the game regarding OpEd, or face irrelevance. At a minimum, don't give us the tripe peddled in this column.
